summary:
Researcher in theoretical biophysics, working closely together with experimenters. We combine analytical models with simulations to study collective dynamics in out-of-equilibrium systems, ranging from the nanoscale of proteins to the macroscale of populations. Bottom-up approach: understanding the relevant processes in living systems by starting with their basic properties and subsequently increasing complexity.

Program director of the MSc Nanobiology (joint degree program between TU Delft and Erasmus University Rotterdam) and teacher in Nanobiology, Physics and Mathematics. Courses range from introductory physics to the cutting edge of current research, including classical mechanics, special relativity, quantum mechanics, soft matter, differential geometry, and genetic engineering. Proponent of open eductation, including the writing and adaptation of open texbooks.

Specialties: analytical modeling, phenomenological descriptions, inter-disciplinary collaborations.

treasury_media.title: Idema group @ TU Delft Bionanoscience
treasury_media.description: We are a (mostly) theoretical biophysics group that has the good fortune to be part of a large department housing both experimentalists and theorists. Our main research interest is the topic of collective dynamics, from the level of single molecules such as proteins and molecular motors, all the way up to cells in tissue and colonies of bacteria.

projects.title: Collective development of open education materials
projects.description: While we all know that the future is multi-disciplinary, the textbooks from which we teach are usually still written from a monodisciplinary perspective. To compensate, many teachers develop their own material. Most of those materials however don’t make it beyond a single class, as teachers lack the time and options to develop them further. Much can be gained by working together, if we have the right tools. In particular, we could develop educational materials in the same spirit in which open software is developed: a combination of the approach of gitlab and Wikipedia, allowing people to contribute to or branch from projects while getting credit for their work. In this project, we will develop the necessary tools and kickstart the collective development of new, open, multi-disciplinary and multi-resources ‘textbooks’, giving teachers new ways to share, and students new ways to learn.

projects.title: Open leermaterialen in een multidisciplinaire opleiding - een brug tussen natuurkunde en biologie
projects.description:
De bachelor- en masteropleiding Nanobiologie slaat een brug tussen toegepaste fysica en medische biologie. Hoewel het programma een groot succes is en er elk jaar meer studenten willen aansluiten dan er mee kunnen doen, is er een gebrek aan specifieke vakliteratuur. De leermaterialen die nu in het onderwijsprogramma worden gebruikt zijn geschreven vanuit een natuurkundig of medisch perspectief en sluiten inhoudelijk en taal technisch niet volledig op elkaar aan. Daarom werkt een community van twaalf docenten van de TUD en de EUR de komende jaren aan een collectie van open leermaterialen in de vorm van interactieve tekstboeken. De nieuwe open leermaterialen moeten ervoor zorgen dat er een gedeelde Nanobiologie-taal ontstaat, studenten gemakkelijker toegang hebben tot kwalitatieve onderwijsmaterialen en er een beter geïntegreerd curriculum ontstaat.

De collectie leermaterialen worden ingezet in het bachelor onderwijs van de opleiding Nanobiologie. Door de onderwijsmaterialen in een open format te delen, kunnen ze ook gemakkelijk worden ingezet en aangevuld door soortgelijke opleidingen.

profile_positions.description:
The goal of the Nanobiology programme is to train students to using the language of maths
and the principles of physics to understand the complexity of biology. We're a joint-degree programme offered by TU Delft and the Erasmus MC (Rotterdam). As programme director, I'm responsible for the programme content.
profile_positions.title: Program Director MSc Nanobiology

profile_positions.description:
As an associate professor, my job consists of two main parts: research and education. The research part involves both my own research and that done by the students I supervise. Our main focus is on collective dynamics in biological systems; you can find detailed descriptions in our publications and on my group website (www.idemalab.tudelft.nl). In parallel, I teach various aspects of physics (including classical mechanics, relativity, quantum mechanics, soft matter and biophysics) to students from the Applied Physics, Applied Mathematics, and Nanobiology programs.

Starting September 2020, I have taken up the directorship of the Nanobiology MSc program, a joint program of TU Delft and the Erasmus Medical Center Rotterdam.
profile_positions.title: Associate Professor

profile_positions.description: As an assistant professor, my job consists of two main parts: research and education. The research part involves both my own research and that done by the students I supervise; you can find detailed descriptions in our publications and on my group website (www.idemalab.tudelft.nl). In parallel, I teach various aspects of physics (including classical mechanics, thermodynamics, relativity, quantum mechanics, and soft matter) to students from the Applied Physics, Applied Mathematics, and Nanobiology programs.
profile_positions.title: Assistant Professor

profile_positions.description: As a postdoc, my main focus was on the theoretical study of the mechanics of developing biological systems, in particular division waves in Drosophila embryos and contraction waves in embryonic chicken hearts. We found that these very different systems are both tuned by mechanical cues, which are directly related to the material properties of the tissue. Consequently, both systems can be seen as examples of a wide class of systems of mechanically excitable media. These projects were again done in close collaboration with experimentalists, and resulted in several publications (see below).
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher

profile_positions.description:
As a PhD student, my main focus was on a research project in theoretical biophysics, studying the shape and dynamics of biological membranes. In parallel, I studied the dynamics of nonprocessive molecular motors interacting with both the membrane and the cytoskeleton of a cell. Both projects were done in close collaboration with experimentalists, and resulted in numerous publications (see list) and a PhD thesis.
Next to research, I tutored undergraduate students in the courses Classical Mechanics 2 and Statistical Physics 1.
